Welcome!
    Adobe Target Overview
    Michael Benefiel
    December 5, 2019
    Table of Contents
      What is Adobe Target?
      Key Concepts
      How Adobe Target Works
      Why Use Adobe Target?
      Adobe Target and Tealium
    Adobe Target
    What is Adobe Target?
      Adobe Target is a rule-based testing and targeting tool, which can integrate with Analytics & create reports that can be used for making marketing offers, personalization and UX testing; allowing marketers to figure out which of the offers, experiences & messages are truly engaging the customers.
    Key Concepts
      Activity: Determines the experiences a site visitor might encounter.
      For example, you might design an activity that tests two different landing pages, one that highlights information about women's summer shoes, and one that highlights more general summer apparel. The activity determines the conditions that control when each of these landing pages appears, and the metrics that determine which page is more successful. The activity is configured to start and end when specific conditions are met, such as between specific dates, or to start when the activity is approved and to end when it is deactivated.
    Key Concepts (cont'd)
      Experiences: Defines the content that displays on your page, as well as other page elements, such as links.
      For example, one experience might have one set of links across the top of the page, where another experience has different links or the same links arranged in a different order. You might want to test whether one image provides more lift than another, or whether an ad is more likely to be clicked near the top of your page or in a different location.
    Key Concepts (cont'd)
      Offers: The content displayed on your webpages during campaigns or activities.
      When you test your webpages, you measure the success of each experience with different offers in your locations. An offer can contain different types of content, including: image, text, html, link, button. For example, a webpage might display either of two offers, depending on whether the visitor has been to your site before. An experience determines which content displays when particular conditions are met.
    Key Concepts (cont'd)
      Audiences: Define the target for your activity and are used anywhere where targeting is available.
      Target audiences are a defined set of visitor criteria. Offers can be targeted to specific audiences (or segments). Only visitors who belong to that audience see the experience that is targeted to them.
      For example, you might target an activity to an audience made up of visitors who use a particular browser or operating system.
    Key Concepts (cont'd)
      A/B Testing: An activity type that compares two or more versions of your site's content to see which version best improves your conversions during a pre-specified test period.
      An A/B test (sometimes referred to as an A/B...N test) compares two or more versions of a web site's content to see which best lifts conversions, sales, or other identified metrics. Use an A/B test to compare changes to a page against the default page design to determine which experience produces the best results.
    How Adobe Target Works
      Adobe Target integrates with websites by means of one of two JavaScript libraries: at.js or mbox.js
      The at.js library is the new implementation library for Target. The at.js library improves page-load times for web implementations and provides better implementation options for single-page applications. The at.js library also includes the components that were included in target.js, so there is no longer a call to target.js. Default Adobe Target Marketplace Version: at.js 1.8.0
      The mbox.js library is the legacy implementation library for Target. The mbox.js library is still supported, but there will be no feature updates.
    How Adobe Target Works (cont'd)
      Each time a visitor requests a page that has been optimized for Target, a request is sent to the targeting system to determine what content to serve to a visitor. This process occurs in real-time — every time a page is loaded, a request for the content is made and fulfilled by the system. The content is governed by the rules of marketer-controlled activities and experiences and is targeted to the individual site visitor. Content is served so that each site visitor is most likely to respond to, interact with, and ultimately purchase, to maximize response rates, acquisition rates, and revenue.
      You must reference the Target JavaScript library file on every page on your site.
    Why Use Adobe Target?
      The main business drivers behind the use of Adobe Target at this point is conversion optimization. It provides intuitive test reports based on different segments such as new and returning users. The tool can be plugged-in with other marketing cloud products as well as other third party marketing tools.
    Why Use Adobe Target (cont'd)?
      Ability to execute multiple tests simultaneously and to segment traffic to particular tests makes Target highly scalable.
      Integration with other tools through plug-ins saves a lot of time and resources.
      Target audiences by device type, operating system, screen size, geolocation, or profile (whether anonymous or registered) to deliver the best experience.
      Easily create, test, and manage automated recommendations for promotions such as cross-sell or upsell within mobile apps or sites.
    Adobe Target | Tealium
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    The mbox
      An mbox is a “marketing box,” which is an area on a web page used by Adobe Target to show different content to visitors in a campaign. Marketers can replace blocks of content in the mbox with dynamic content that they’ve created in Adobe Target. The content displayed inside an mbox during a campaign is called an offer.
      Adobe Target has two methods that can be used to modify content: Place Regional mboxes in pages in the exact locations where content will be modified. Place a Global mbox create statement in the page and define all logic within the Adobe Target interface as to which content will be modified.
    Adobe Target and TiQ
    What is Flicker?
      Flicker is the occurrence of default content being momentarily displayed to the visitor before it is replaced with the content you intended to show the visitor, making it seem to the visitor that the content flickered. Visitors can sometimes interpret flicker as a problem with the site, potentially causing the visitor to lose confidence in the site or brand. Flicker can also cause visitor dissatisfaction if, for example, they see a discount they like "flicker away" to be replaced with a lesser discount. Flicker is a symptom of encountering a delay in loading the content displayed, also called "tests", asynchronously.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Flicker Free
      Tealium supports both asynchronous and synchronous versions of the Adobe Target tag. The asynchronous version is recommended. However, if you choose to load your tests synchronously, you will not see flicker occur. However, loading content synchronously means that the entire page must wait to receive that content before it parses and displays the rest of the page.
      Asynchronous loading circumvents the issue of unavailable content halting page load because the browser continues to load the rest of the page while it waits for the pending content. However, if there is a long enough delay between the browser encountering the offer on the page and retrieving the offer's content, visitors may briefly see the default content. This is the flicker phenomenon.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Flicker Free: First Approach
      Eliminate flicker by taking Adobe Target module (config) and placing within utag.sync.
      When the page loads, the browser will encounter the utag.sync.js file which sets the CSS visibility property to "hidden". The content is not removed, but the browser will not render it. The layout dimensions of the hidden content are preserved, so the layout of your page is not deformed. To a visitor it will appear as though the section where the content would be displayed is blank instead. There is no flicker.
      When the utag.js file loads, it calls Adobe Target which in turn shows the hidden nodes.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Flicker Free: Second Approach
      The Adobe Target Content Modification extension is used with Adobe Target to change the content of an HTML element and can be used to show A/B content based on a condition.The synchronous load does not use the extension.
      To implement extension, set DOM ID and mbox ID. Tealium will inject this extension code into utag.sync file. Need to delete fields and republish. Tealium will continue to inject in utag.sync. Scope to Adobe Target tag.
      This extension requires initialization code. This must be done by placing the utag.sync.js snippet in the head section of your page.
      After you have enabled the publish setting, you must re-publish your profile. Republishing generates the utag.sync.js file and pushes it onto Tealium's multi-CDN infrastructure. If you do not publish after enabling the publish setting, any page that references the utag.sync.js file will not be able to find it, potentially causing page load failure.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Using Global mbox with utag.sync.js
      This method allows you to keep your Tealium implementation asynchronous, but load the Global mbox synchronously.
      Enable utag.sync
      Code utag.sync into head of page
      Download mbox.js
      Locally host mbox.js
      Configure utag.sync
var mboxjs_location = "//path/to/mbox.js";
var global_mbox_name = "Global mbox name";
document.write('<script src="' + mboxjs_location + '"></script>');
document.write('<script type="text/javascript">mboxCreate("'+global_mbox_name+'")</script>');
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Pass Parameters to a global mbox
      The JavaScript targetPageParams function is used to pass parameters to the global mbox. This is needed in any scenario where additional targeting/context information is to be passed into Target.
      For example, in a Recommendations activity, use the parameters to represent the current product or category that is being viewed.
      The code to call the JavaScript function must come before the global mbox on the page, whether the global mbox is fired as a part of mbox.js or is manually included in the page code.
      Can usually be implemented via mappings within Adobe Target Marketplace tag.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    at.js functions
      mboxCreate(). This function is available for at.js versions 1. x only. This function was deprecated with the release of at.js 2.x. This function returns default content if used with at.js 2.x. This function is built into at.js mostly to ease the transition from mbox.js to at.js. A newer alternative to mboxCreate() is adobe.target.getOffer() / adobe.target.applyOffer()
      adobe.target.triggerView (viewName, options) - at.js 2.x. This function can be called whenever a new page is loaded or when a component on a page is re-rendered. adobe.target.triggerView() should be implemented for single page applications (SPAs) in order to use the Visual Experience Composer (VEC) to create A/B Tests and Experience Targeting (XT) activities.
      adobe.target.trackEvent(options). This function fires a request to report user actions, such as clicks and conversions.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    at.js function: adobe.target.getOffer(options)
      This function fires a request to get a Target offer.
      Use with adobe.target.applyOffer() to process the response or use your own success handling. The options parameter is mandatory and has a defined structure found here: https://docs.adobe.com/content/help/en/target/using/implement-target/client-side/functions-overview/adobe-target-getoffer.html
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Target & Experience Cloud ID
      If you’re using Adobe Experience Cloud ID service (Adobe Analytics Visitor API), Cloud ID needs to be called first. If using Adobe Target and Cloud ID service tag, the experience cloud is put on top and loaded first because of its settings.
      If Adobe Target module is in utag.sync, then Visitor API needs to be loaded before in utag.sync. Use that as opposed to using Experience Cloud ID tag.
    Adobe Target and AudienceStream
      Connector doesn't load Adobe Target; it simply updates the user's Adobe profile with mapped connector data.
